greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: Array of the coefficients A(n,k) in the expansion of Product_{i>=1} 1/(1-x^i)^n  = Sum_{k>=0} A(n,k)*x^k, n >= 1, k >= 0.
comment: Table read by antidiagonals: entry (n,k) gives number of partitions of n objects into parts of k kinds. - _Franklin T. Adams-Watters_, Dec 28 2006
formula: G.f. A(n;x) for n-th row satisfies A(n;x) = Sum_{k=1..n} A000041(k-1)*A(n-k;x)*x^(k-1), A(0;x) = 1. - _Vladeta Jovovic_, Jan 02 2004
example: Table (row k, k >= 0: number of partitions of n, n >= 0, into parts of k kinds):

Triangle (row n, n >= 0: number of partitions of n into parts of n - k kinds, 0 <= k <= n) (antidiagonals of above table) (parenthesized last term on each row, which would correspond to row k = 0 in above table)
Triangle begins: (column k: n - k kinds of parts)
mathematica: t[n_, k_] := CoefficientList[ Series[ Product[1/(1 - x^i)^n, {i, k}], {x, 0, k}], x][[k]]; (* _Robert G. Wilson v_, Aug 08 2018 *)
t[n_, k_]; = IntegerPartitions[n, {k}]; Table[ t[n - k + 1, k], {n, 12}, {k, n}] // Flatten (* _Robert G. Wilson v_, Aug 08 2018 *)
xref: Cf. A067687 (table antidiagonal sums, triangle row sums).
Rows (table), diagonals (triangle): A000041, A000712, A000716, A023003-A023021, A006922.
results.author: Bo T. Ahlander (ahlboa(AT)isk.kth.se), May 03 2001
